awd_titl_txt: QII-TAQS: Enhancing Quantum Coherence by Dissipation in Programmable Atomic Arrays
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum systems with robust coherence are essential in the quest for controllable and scalable quantum technologies. For example, highly coherent quantum systems are needed for the construction of quantum sensors, which can measure time, electromagnetic forces, and gravity with the highest precision, and for a future quantum computer, which promises to speed up data processing to levels unachievable with conventional silicon-based computer technology. However, most of today's quantum applications rely on the limited coherence of individual quantum systems, such as nuclear spins, electron spins, or electronic excitations. This project will demonstrate that coherence can be boosted beyond the limitations of individual quantum systems. The researchers will exploit collective effects in ordered atomic arrays, in which individual atoms will be trapped in close proximity. In this special arrangement the atoms will interact and are expected to display subradiance - a quantum mechanical effect that prevents the atoms from losing internal quantum excitations - which will boost the coherence of atomic quantum systems. To realize these novel concepts experimentally, the researchers will develop and implement a novel nanophotonic platform to trap and position individual atoms with optical tweezers, miniature traps made out of laser light. The project will train undergraduate and graduate students in experimental and theoretical atomic physics, quantum optics, and nanophotonics, and thereby contribute to a highly trained workforce in quantum science and technology.

The research team combines expertise in theoretical quantum optics, experimental atomic physics, and nanophotonics. The experimental system will rely on arrays of laser-cooled strontium atoms trapped by optical tweezers with sub-micrometer spacings. The tweezer array will be generated via projection through a holographic spatial light modulator that will allow for independent control of both the intensity and phase of the trapping light field and enable the generation of optical arrays with unprecedented accuracy and high-speed tunability. With interatomic distances comparable to the atomic resonance wavelength, interference in photon emission gives rise to strongly correlated atomic states that are protected from decay, and thus have substantially longer coherence times than a single atom in free space. The researchers will develop protocols, both theoretically and experimentally, that enable accessing and exploiting the unconventional physical properties of these exotic quantum states. 

This project is jointly funded by the Quantum Leap Big Idea Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

In this collaborative research effort, we have developed theoretical foundations, novel photonics methods, and a next-generation experimental platform to observe super- and subradiance in ordered atomic arrays. Superradiance holds the potential to lead to ultraprecise lasers and enhanced atom-light interfaces, which will be useful for fast-access quantum memories and networking of atomic quantum devices. Subradiance offers the potential to fundamentally enhance the coherence time of quantum states, which will be relevant for long-lived quantum memories, quantum sensors with enhanced sensitivity, and atomic clocks with higher precision. 

The project has made significant breakthroughs. These include: (1) Single atom trapping, cooling, and imaging in optical tweezer arrays in a newly developed next-generation platform for ultracold strontium. The experimental apparatus includes a new compact 2D magneto-optical trap, which simplifies the use of strontium in atomic quantum devices, such as ultraprecise atomic clocks, quantum simulators, and quantum computers. (2) Demonstration of metasurface atom traps. We have developed a novel integrated photonics approach to generate 1D, 2D, and 3D arrays of cold atoms in arbitrary geometries, leveraging the flexibility of holographic metasurfaces for beam shaping. The compact form factor, good power handling capabilities, and scalability of metasurface arrays make them uniquely suited for realizing field-deployable devices based on cold atoms. (3) Comprehensive theoretical models of super- and subradiance in atomic arrays with one-, two-, and many-photon excitations. The theory work has led to the idea of "atomic waveguides" that open the door to novel ways of atoms interacting with light and atoms interacting with each other. Finally, we have performed in-depth studies of experimentally viable approaches to realize super- and subradiance with strontium that take the full complexity of real atoms into account. 

This project has been highly productive, having led to 20+ research papers, 2 inventions, and 100+ invited research talks by the PIs and participating students.

Broader Impacts:

The project has provided extensive hands-on training in quantum science and technology for a dozen undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs. 5 undergraduate students involved in the project have started graduate school in quantum, 2 graduate students have joined photonics and quantum technology companies, 1 postdoc has joined a quantum technology startup, and 2 postdocs have taken academic positions in the field. The effort has been complemented by the development of cross-disciplinary quantum computing and quantum optics courses for undergraduate and graduate students, an outreach program to involve underrepresented high-school students into quantum research, and outreach events to raise public awareness for modern quantum technologies.
